topic.title: Built-In Self Test

note.p: Remove in RevBThis feature is only available in the revision B switch

body.p: The firmware BIST (Built-In Self Test) is a service to help identify any potential issues during the boot-up phase. Please refer to Switchtec Firmware User's Manual for the details of BIST APIs.

section.title: BIST Coverage and Test Patterns
section.p: BIST covers Cache/RAM in SOC chip, RST CAM/LUT RAM in each stack, Switch Port and Switch Core(internal loopback BIST) and firmware/hardware channels in PPU. SOC BIST is executed in the second stage of Bootloader (BL2), Internal loopback BIST, CAM BIST are executed after BL2 during firmware initialization, and PPU BIST is executed in thread context.
Before calling the BIST function, the stack is set up. The BIST verifies the entire memory besides stack memory first, then it verifies the stack memory.

li.p: MIPS L1 I-Cache: L1 cache is initialized in Bootloader BL1, L1 I-Cache BIST will be executed in Bootloader BL2 using Cache Fill and Cache Load instruction in un-cached mode
MIPS L1/L2 D-Cache: Firmware tests L1/L2 D-Cache implicitly through testing OCR and L2 RAM using cached-address.
MIPS L2 RAM: Some L2 cache is locked as L2 RAM. L2 RAM BIST will be executed in cache address and cover all test patterns
DPRAM (Dual Port RAM): Using un-cached address to cover all the patterns.Firmware skips the first 256 bytes which are used for reset reason.
OCR (On Chip RAM): Read/write the entire OCR memory via firmware in cached mode with all test patterns. Firmware skips the last 1024 bytes which are used for firmware boot time profile.

RST (Rule Search Table) CAM/LUT RAM: Firmware uses hardware registers to access RST CAM/LUT RAMs indirectly. Not all register bits are mapped to the CAM/LUT directly, so a mask for each register is defined to write/read/compare the patterns by the mask. All RST CAM/LUT RAMs used by firmware will be tested with the pattern except walking patterns

It covers PPU, Switch Core, Switch Port and PL/DL. First, it will set internal loopback in each physical port. Second, it will transmit TLPs to those looped ports. When the TLPs reach the physical port's egress side, it will be looped back to the ingress side of the physical port, and will be forwarded back to the PPU based on the pre-configured routing rules.
7 PPU firmware channels: Firmware does loopback test using 3 types of TLPs (P/NP/C) among these 7 PPU firmware channels
1 PPU hardware channel: Firmware triggers MemWr64(MSI/MSI-X) through PPU hardware channel to other 7 PPU firmware channels

section.p: BIST test patterns are listed as below:

note.p: The walking 0 and walking 1 for L1 I-Cache test is Address based, e.g. set DWord 0 0x0000_0001, DWord 1 0x0000_0002 and DWord 2 0x0000_0004, …, only one loop is tested.

section.p: If BIST is enabled, the boot time will increase:

row.entry: CAM/RST, Internal Loopback and PPU BIST

section.title: BIST Configuration
section.p: By default, BIST is disabled. An API boot_bist_en() is provided to enable BIST and configure the BIST options.
GPIO configuration API bist_gpio_cfg() provides the option to select a GPIO to indicate a BIST failure.

section.title: BIST Error Handling
section.p: IWhen an error occur from BIST, the selected GPIO (configured using bist_pgio_cfg()) will output a high or low signal to indicate the failure while firmware remains in the boot-up phase. Firmware will not drop to safe mode or minimal mode if there is a BIST failure.
